title: Micah Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Micah chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Micah Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Micah Chapter 2.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:1, when do the people practise iniquity?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:1 states they practise it when the morning is light because it is in the power of their hand.

questions.question: What do the people covet and take by violence as mentioned in Micah 2:2?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:2 says they covet fields and take them by violence, also houses and take them away.

questions.question: In Micah 2:3, what will the people not be able to remove from their necks?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:3 explains that God devises an evil against this family from which they shall not remove their necks.

questions.question: What does the lamentation in Micah 2:4 say has been changed and removed?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:4 states the lamentation is about the portion of my people being changed and removed.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:5, what shall there be none to cast in the congregation of the LORD?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:5 declares there shall be none casting a cord by lot in the congregation of the LORD.

questions.question: Who tells the prophets 'Prophesy ye not' in Micah 2:6?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:6 shows that those opposed to prophecy tell the prophets not to prophesy.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 2:7 states that God's words do good to those who walk uprightly.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:7 asks if the spirit of the LORD is straitened and confirms that God's words do good to him that walketh uprightly.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:8, what have the people pulled off from those passing by securely?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:8 describes pulling off the robe with the garment from those passing by securely.

questions.question: Who have been cast out from their pleasant houses as per Micah 2:9?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:9 says the women of God's people have been cast out from their pleasant houses.

questions.question: What does Micah 2:10 command the people to do because it is not their rest?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:10 instructs the people to arise and depart because this is not their rest.

questions.question: True or False: According to Micah 2:11, a man lying in the spirit and falsehood will prophesy about wine and strong drink.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:11 states that a man lying in spirit and falsehood says he will prophesy of wine and strong drink.

questions.question: Who does God say He will assemble in Micah 2:12?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:12 says God will assemble and gather the remnant of Israel.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:13, who shall pass before the people as the breaker?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:13 says their king shall pass before them, and the LORD on the head of them as the breaker.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Micah 2:1: 'Woe to them that devise ______, and work evil upon their beds!'
questions.explanation: Micah 2:1 begins with 'Woe to them that devise iniquity, and work evil upon their beds!'

questions.question: True or False: Micah 2:5 says people will cast cords by lot in the congregation of the LORD.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:5 clearly states that there shall be none that cast a cord by lot in the congregation of the LORD.

medium.title: Micah Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Micah Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with greed and taking advantage of others. Based on Micah 2, what biblical truth would you share about honesty and integrity in work?
options: Woe to those who devise iniquity and work evil, for God opposes those who take by violence.
It is acceptable to take what is not yours if no one sees.
God rewards those who covet fields and houses by violence.
Those who work hard to gain wealth will always be blessed.
questions.correctAnswer: Woe to those who devise iniquity and work evil, for God opposes those who take by violence.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:1-2 warns against devising evil and taking fields or houses by violence, emphasizing God’s opposition to such injustice. This teaches believers to practice honesty and integrity in their work.

questions.question: How does Micah 2 teach us about humility when facing difficult circumstances in life?
options: Do not go haughtily because the time is evil and God is devising judgment.
Be proud and boast of your strength to overcome trials.
Ignore God’s warnings and continue your own way.
Trust only in your own power to survive hardships.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not go haughtily because the time is evil and God is devising judgment.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:3 instructs that during evil times, people should not be haughty but humble, recognizing God’s sovereign judgment and their need to trust Him.

questions.question: A believer feels wronged by others taking their inheritance. What hope does Micah 2 offer about God’s justice and restoration?
options: God will assemble and gather the remnant of Israel like sheep in a fold.
There is no hope; loss is final.
One must fight violently to reclaim what was taken.
God ignores the plight of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God will assemble and gather the remnant of Israel like sheep in a fold.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:12 promises God’s gathering and protection of His people, symbolizing restoration and hope despite injustice.

questions.question: How does Micah 2 instruct believers regarding false prophecy and spiritual discipline?
options: False prophets who lie about wine and strong drink are considered prophets of this people.
All who claim to prophesy must be accepted without question.
Prophesying of pleasant things is always true.
Spiritual discipline is unnecessary if one speaks boldly.
questions.correctAnswer: False prophets who lie about wine and strong drink are considered prophets of this people.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:11 warns about false prophets who deceive with promises of wine and strong drink, teaching the need for discernment and spiritual integrity.

questions.question: What does Micah 2 teach about contentment and trusting God’s provision?
options: Do not seek rest where it is polluted; depart and find true rest in God.
Rest is found in possessions and wealth.
Contentment comes from accumulating more fields and houses.
Trust in worldly power to secure your future.
questions.correctAnswer: Do not seek rest where it is polluted; depart and find true rest in God.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:10 advises departing from polluted rest, implying that true contentment and rest come from trusting God rather than worldly wealth or power.

questions.question: A church leader questions why prophecy sometimes seems ineffective. How does Micah 2 address faithfulness in God's promises and church life?
options: God’s words are for good to those who walk uprightly, not to shame them.
Prophecy is always ineffective and should be ignored.
The spirit of the Lord is limited and cannot help His people.
God does not care about the righteousness of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s words are for good to those who walk uprightly, not to shame them.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:7 affirms that God’s words benefit those who live uprightly, encouraging faithfulness and obedience in the church.

questions.question: True or False: According to Micah 2, God will punish those who oppress others and take what belongs to them by violence.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:2-3 clearly states that God devises evil against those who oppress and take by violence, showing His judgment on such behavior.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 2 encourages believers to prophesy only positive and comforting messages regardless of truth.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:6-7 shows that God’s words are meant for good but warns against false prophecy that ignores truth, emphasizing integrity in speaking God’s message.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Micah 2 teaches that the LORD will gather the remnant of Israel as the sheep of _____, making great noise by the multitude of men.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:12 uses the imagery of sheep in Bozrah to describe God's gathering and protection of His people.

questions.question: How does Micah 2 illustrate the importance of humility instead of arrogance in times of judgment?
options: You shall not remove your necks nor go haughtily because the time is evil.
Be arrogant and proud to overcome hardship.
Ignore God's judgment and continue as you please.
Trust only in your own power to avoid consequences.
questions.correctAnswer: You shall not remove your necks nor go haughtily because the time is evil.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:3 warns against arrogance and instructs humility during times of God's judgment, teaching reliance on Him.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to ignore the suffering of others. Based on Micah 2, what biblical principle about love and justice would you share?
options: Oppressing a man and his heritage is condemned by God.
It is acceptable to ignore others’ suffering.
God supports those who seek gain by oppression.
questions.correctAnswer: Oppressing a man and his heritage is condemned by God.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:2 condemns coveting and taking others' fields and houses by violence, teaching believers to love neighbors and act justly.

questions.question: How does Micah 2 encourage perseverance through trials and trust in God’s leadership?
options: The breaker has come before them, and their king shall pass before them, led by the LORD.
One must rely solely on human strength to overcome trials.
Trials are a sign that God has abandoned His people.
God’s leadership is hidden and inaccessible.
questions.correctAnswer: The breaker has come before them, and their king shall pass before them, led by the LORD.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:13 describes God leading and breaking through for His people, encouraging trust and perseverance under His guidance.

questions.question: What does Micah 2 teach about the consequences of ignoring God's commands in family and community life?
options: Women and children suffer loss of their pleasant homes and God's glory is taken away.
Ignoring God’s commands has no consequences.
Family life will prosper regardless of obedience.
Community life is separate from God’s law.
questions.correctAnswer: Women and children suffer loss of their pleasant homes and God's glory is taken away.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:9 highlights the suffering of families when God’s ways are disregarded, stressing the importance of obedience for family and community well-being.

questions.question: How does Micah 2 demonstrate the importance of genuine prophecy for church life and spiritual growth?
options: True prophecy benefits those who walk uprightly and brings no shame.
Prophecy should always promise prosperity no matter what.
False prophecy is acceptable if it comforts people.
Prophets should avoid speaking hard truths.
questions.correctAnswer: True prophecy benefits those who walk uprightly and brings no shame.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:7 teaches that God’s words are beneficial for the upright, emphasizing the role of truthful prophecy in spiritual growth.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by seeing others prosper through dishonest means. What biblical truth from Micah 2 would encourage perseverance in integrity?
options: God will execute judgment against the violent and oppressors, and gather His faithful remnant.
Dishonesty is the quickest way to success.
God ignores injustice and rewards the strong.
One must conform to the ways of the world to survive.
questions.correctAnswer: God will execute judgment against the violent and oppressors, and gather His faithful remnant.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:3 and 2:12 assure that God judges oppressors and gathers His people, encouraging believers to remain faithful and persevere with integrity.

hard.title: Micah Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Micah Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Micah 2:1, what time of day do the wicked begin to practice their evil deeds?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:1 states that the wicked devise iniquity and work evil upon their beds and practise it when the morning is light.

questions.question: Micah 2:2 describes those who covet fields and take them by what means?
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly says they covet fields and take them by violence, highlighting the injustice.

questions.question: What does the LORD say He will devise against the family mentioned in Micah 2:3?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:3 states that the LORD will devise an evil against this family from which they shall not remove their necks.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:4, what lamentation will be taken up against the people?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:4 describes a lamentation that says, 'We be utterly spoiled,' reflecting loss of land and inheritance.

questions.question: Micah 2:5 says there will be none to cast a cord by lot in what assembly?
questions.explanation: This verse indicates that because of the judgment, no one will cast lots for land in the LORD's assembly.

questions.question: Who tells the prophets not to prophesy in Micah 2:6?
questions.explanation: The verse says 'they' tell the prophets not to prophesy, indicating opposition from the people toward true prophecy.

questions.question: In Micah 2:7, what question is posed about the spirit of the LORD and His doings?
options: Is the spirit of the LORD straitened? Are these His doings?
Is the LORD angry? Will He destroy us?
Is the LORD pleased? Shall we prosper?
Is the LORD silent? Will He forget us?
questions.correctAnswer: Is the spirit of the LORD straitened? Are these His doings?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:7 questions whether the LORD's spirit is restricted and if the evil events are truly from Him, challenging false assumptions.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Micah 2:8 to describe how the people have risen up against each other?
options: Pulling off the robe with the garment
questions.correctAnswer: Pulling off the robe with the garment
questions.explanation: The verse uses the vivid image of pulling off garments from those passing securely, symbolizing betrayal and violence.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:9, what have the oppressors taken away from the women and children of the people?
questions.explanation: Verse 2:9 states that women were cast out of their pleasant houses and children had the glory taken away forever.

questions.question: Micah 2:10 commands the people to do what because the place is polluted?
questions.explanation: The verse commands departing because the place is polluted and will bring destruction.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Micah 2:11: 'If a man walking in the spirit and falsehood do lie, saying, I will prophesy unto thee of ___ and of strong drink.'
questions.explanation: The verse mentions wine and strong drink as the false prophecy topics.

questions.question: What analogy does Micah 2:12 use to describe how God will gather the remnant of Israel?
options: As the sheep of Bozrah, as the flock in the midst of their fold
As the stars in the sky
As the rivers to the sea
As the grains of sand on the shore
questions.correctAnswer: As the sheep of Bozrah, as the flock in the midst of their fold
questions.explanation: The verse uses the pastoral image of a shepherd gathering sheep to illustrate God's care.

questions.question: Who is described as 'the breaker' that comes up before the people in Micah 2:13?
questions.explanation: The breaker is identified as the king who leads the people forward, with the LORD at their head.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 2:6 suggests that the people welcomed true prophecy without shame.
questions.explanation: The verse states that the people tell the prophets not to prophesy to avoid shame, indicating rejection of true prophecy.

questions.question: True or False: The lamentation in Micah 2:4 includes a complaint about the removal and division of the people’s fields.
questions.explanation: Micah 2:4 describes a doleful lamentation complaining about changed portions and divided fields.

theological.title: Micah Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Micah Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:1, what characterizes those who devise iniquity?
options: They work evil upon their beds and practice it in the morning
They seek justice for the oppressed
questions.correctAnswer: They work evil upon their beds and practice it in the morning
questions.explanation: Micah 2:1 states that those who devise iniquity work evil upon their beds and practice it as soon as morning comes, indicating persistent, deliberate sin. This is consistent with Jeremiah 17:9, Psalm 36:1, Romans 1:29, and 1 John 3:8, which describe the deceitfulness and persistence of sin.

questions.question: What sin is specifically condemned in Micah 2:2?
options: Coveting fields and houses and taking them by violence
Idolatry and sacrificing to other gods
questions.correctAnswer: Coveting fields and houses and taking them by violence
questions.explanation: Micah 2:2 condemns coveting fields and houses and forcibly taking them, oppressing others. This aligns with the biblical prohibition against covetousness and unjust acquisition found in Exodus 20:17, Proverbs 22:22, Isaiah 5:8, and Luke 12:15.

questions.question: What divine response is declared in Micah 2:3 regarding the oppressors?
options: God devises evil against them from which they cannot remove their necks
God promises to bless them abundantly
questions.correctAnswer: God devises evil against them from which they cannot remove their necks
questions.explanation: Micah 2:3 declares God's judgment against the oppressors, emphasizing that they will be held accountable and unable to escape punishment. This theme of divine judgment is echoed in Isaiah 10:1-2, Ezekiel 7:3, Romans 12:19, and Revelation 6:10-11.

questions.question: In Micah 2:4, what lament is spoken against those who have taken away the portion of the people?
options: "We be utterly spoiled; he hath changed the portion of my people."
"The LORD has blessed us with abundance."
"Our enemies have been defeated in battle."
"Peace and prosperity reign in our land."
questions.correctAnswer: "We be utterly spoiled; he hath changed the portion of my people."
questions.explanation: Micah 2:4 records a lament over the loss of land and inheritance, reflecting the consequences of injustice. Similar laments occur in Jeremiah 12:7, Lamentations 5:1, Psalm 44:9-10, and Isaiah 5:7 where God’s people mourn loss due to sin and judgment.

questions.question: What does Micah 2:5 say about casting a cord by lot in the congregation of the LORD?
options: There shall be none to do so
It shall be done with great joy
It shall be the privilege of the priests only
It shall be a sign of blessing
questions.correctAnswer: There shall be none to do so
questions.explanation: Micah 2:5 predicts the absence of those who draw lots for inheritance or land within God's congregation, indicating loss of property and blessing. This resonates with the loss of inheritance themes in Numbers 26:55, Joshua 7:2, Ezekiel 46:16, and Acts 1:26.

questions.question: How do the people respond to the prophets according to Micah 2:6?
options: They say, "Prophesy ye not," forbidding them to speak
They honor and support the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They say, "Prophesy ye not," forbidding them to speak
questions.explanation: Micah 2:6 shows that the people reject the prophets, refusing to hear their messages. This rejection of God's word is a recurring theme found in Jeremiah 6:10, Ezekiel 2:7, 2 Chronicles 36:16, and Hebrews 12:25.

questions.question: What question does God ask the house of Jacob in Micah 2:7 that challenges their perception of His Spirit?
options: "Is the spirit of the LORD straitened? Are these his doings?"
questions.correctAnswer: "Is the spirit of the LORD straitened? Are these his doings?"
questions.explanation: Micah 2:7 questions whether God's Spirit is limited or constrained, challenging false assumptions about God's character and actions. This aligns with Isaiah 59:1, John 3:8, Romans 8:9, and 2 Corinthians 3:17 emphasizing the freedom and power of the Spirit.

questions.question: What injustice is described in Micah 2:8 regarding the people and their garments?
options: The people pull off robes and garments from those passing securely
The people generously clothe the poor
The priests wear fine linen before the Lord
The people share their garments with strangers
questions.correctAnswer: The people pull off robes and garments from those passing securely
questions.explanation: Micah 2:8 describes violent robbery and humiliation of the people by others, symbolized by stripping garments. This injustice is echoed in Isaiah 3:24, Ezekiel 16:37, Matthew 27:28, and James 2:15-16 where the vulnerable are mistreated.

questions.question: According to Micah 2:9, who are cast out from their pleasant houses?
questions.explanation: Micah 2:9 states that the women of God's people are cast out from their homes, highlighting the social devastation caused by injustice. This is consistent with the lament over desolation found in Lamentations 5:11, Isaiah 3:26, Jeremiah 5:8, and Ezekiel 7:26.

questions.question: What command is given in Micah 2:10 regarding those who are not to find rest there?
options: Arise and depart, for this is not your rest
Pray for blessings on the land
questions.correctAnswer: Arise and depart, for this is not your rest
questions.explanation: Micah 2:10 exhorts the people to leave because the land is polluted and will bring destruction. This theme of exile as judgment is found in Deuteronomy 28:63, Jeremiah 25:11, Ezekiel 12:15, and Hebrews 13:14.

questions.question: In Micah 2:11, what kind of man is said to prophesy of wine and strong drink?
options: A man walking in the spirit and falsehood
A man of great humility and truth
A prophet filled with the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: A man walking in the spirit and falsehood
questions.explanation: Micah 2:11 describes a false prophet who lies claiming to prophesy about wine and strong drink, symbolizing drunkenness and deception. False prophecy is condemned in Deuteronomy 18:20, Jeremiah 23:16, Ezekiel 13:6, and 2 Peter 2:1.

questions.question: What does God promise to do in Micah 2:12 regarding the remnant of Israel?
options: Assemble and gather them as sheep in a fold
questions.correctAnswer: Assemble and gather them as sheep in a fold
questions.explanation: Micah 2:12 promises God will gather the remnant of Israel like sheep, indicating care and restoration. This shepherd imagery is consistent with Ezekiel 34:11-16, John 10:11, Psalm 23:1-4, and Hebrews 13:20.

questions.question: Who is described as 'the breaker' in Micah 2:13?
options: The king who leads the people out
questions.correctAnswer: The king who leads the people out
questions.explanation: Micah 2:13 portrays the breaker as one who breaks through gates and leads the people, symbolizing a messianic figure leading deliverance. This is echoed in Psalm 24:7-10, Isaiah 42:13, Luke 19:38, and Revelation 19:11-16 where Christ is the victorious king.

questions.question: What attribute of God is emphasized by His gathering of the remnant in Micah 2:12?
questions.explanation: The gathering of the remnant as sheep shows God's pastoral care and faithfulness, consistent with Ezekiel 34:11-16, John 10:14, Psalm 100:3, and Isaiah 40:11.

questions.question: What is the eschatological significance of the 'king' going before the people in Micah 2:13?
options: It anticipates the Messianic King leading salvation
It refers only to historical kings of Israel
It indicates the end of God's covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates the Messianic King leading salvation
questions.explanation: The 'king' leading the people is understood messianically, pointing to Christ who leads final salvation (Micah 5:2, Isaiah 9:6, Zechariah 9:9, Revelation 19:16). This is an eschatological hope of God’s deliverance.
